abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            rated as satisfactory. The key lessons learned include: 1)
            Although this project has been highly innovative in
            supporting one of the first rail transport decentralization
            initiatives in the world, a more gradual transition would
            have likely minimized the difficulties associated with the
            actual transfer. 2) Despite the fact that the state-owned
            operating agency is better placed than Brazilian Urban Train
            Company (CBTU) to respond to local realities, Metropolitan
            Train Company of Sao Paulo (CPTM) is still constrained by
            political interference and bureaucratic red tape, which
            affects its productivity. This is best addressed through a
            concession to the private sector. Decentralization is,
            therefore, only a mandatory stopover to greater private
            sector participation. 3) In systems where there is
            substantial fare evasion, it is important to challenge base
            data on evasion estimates more thoroughly and periodically
            than was done by CBTU. The impact of fare evasion should not
            be underestimated as it has led to inaccurate estimates of
            total passenger traffic and the amount of operating
            subsidies required. 4) The issue of whether to purchase new
            trains or rehabilitate existing trains was heavily debated
            during appraisal. The Borrower opted for rehabilitation due
            to lower costs and relatively shorter time periods involved.
            Given the delays experienced, it might have been preferable
            to have opted for a mix of rehabilitated and new trains.
